sources.name: Engines of Liberation (research paper)
sources.description:
Greenwood, Seshadri and Yorukoglu (2005) – Engines of Liberation
Data provider Greenwood, Seshadri and Yorukoglu (2005) – Engines of Liberation
Source Jeremy Greenwood, Ananth Seshadri and Mehmet Yorukoglu (2005), "Engines of Liberation," Review of Economic Studies, v. 72, n. 1: 109-133.
Description The diffusion of  common electrical appliances through American households over time
Linkhttps://urresearch.rochester.edu/institutionalPublicationPublicView.action?institutionalItemId=127
Retrieved13/10/2015

Additional information

Abstract of the paper
Electricity was born at the dawn of the last century. Households were inundated with a flood of new consumer durable goods. What was the impact of this consumer durable goods revolution? It is argued here that the consumer goods revolution was conducive to liberating women from the home. To analyze this hypothesis, a Beckerian model of household production is developed. Households must decide whether to adopt the new technologies or not, and whether married woman should work. Can such a model help to explain the rise in married female labor-force participation that occurred in the last century? Yes.
